Fig. 1 (a) N2 adsorption-desorption isotherms and (b) mean pore size diameter distribution of the calcined Ce, Mg-Ce and La-Mg-Ce supports. Fig. 1 Fig. 2 XRD patterns of the calcined Ce, Mg-Ce, La-Mg-Ce and calcined Li/Ce, Li/Mg-Ce, Li/La-Mg-Ce catalysts in the 10–70o (a,b) and 27–31o (c,d) areas. Fig. 2 Fig. 3 (a) Raman spectra of the calcined supporting materials, and (b–d) Raman spectra of the calcined Li/Ce, Li/Mg-Ce and Li/La-Mg-Ce catalysts. Fig. 3 Fig. 4 CO2-TPD profiles of the (a) calcined supports and (b) Li-based catalytic samples. Fig. 4 Fig. 5 H2-TPR profiles of the Ce, Mg-Ce and La-Mg-Ce supports. Fig. 5 Fig. 6 XPS analysis of O 1s peak for (a) the calcined supports and (b) the Li based catalysts. Fig. 6 Fig. 7 Catalytic performance for Li/Ce, Li/Mg-Ce and Li/La-Mg-Ce as a function of reaction temperature: (a) CH4 conversion, (b) C2H4 and C2H6 selectivity, and CO selectivity, (c) C2H4 and C2H6 Yield, and (d) Molar ratio of C2H4/C2H6; Reaction conditions: Experimental Protocol #1; see text for discussion. Fig. 7 Fig. 8 Catalytic performance for Li/Ce, Li/Mg-Ce and Li/La-Mg-Ce as a function of reaction temperature: (a) CH4 conversion, (b) C2H4 and C2H6 selectivity, and CO and CO2 selectivity, (c) C2H4 and C2H6 yield and (d) Molar ratio of C2H4/C2H6; Reaction conditions: Experimental Protocol #2; see text for discussion. Fig. 8 Fig. 9 Stability tests for Li/La-Mg-Ce as a function of reaction time: (a) CH4 conversion and C2 yield, (b) C2 and COx selectivity and (c) Molar ratio C2H4/C2H6; Reaction conditions: Experimental Protocol #3; see text for discussion. Fig. 9 Table 1 Specific surface area, pore volume, and pore size of the calcined supports and Li-based catalysts. Box 127788 Abu Dhabi United Arab Emirates The work presented herein reports on the oxidative coupling of methane (OCM) performance of a series of Li-free and Li-doped CeO2 and CeO2 modified with Mg2+ and La3+ catalysts. The supporting materials (Ce, Mg-Ce and La-Mg-Ce metal oxides) were synthesized using the microwave assisted sol-gel method, while lithium ions were added using the wet impregnation technique, to further affect the physicochemical properties, activity and selectivity of the materials, in terms of the desirable hydrocarbon products (C2H4 and C2H6). The materials were characterized towards their textural, structural and redox properties, surface basicity, and surface morphology using N2 adsorption/desorption, X-Ray Diffraction (XRD), Raman spectroscopy, CO2-Temperature Programmed Desorption (CO2-TPD), H2-Temperature Programmed Reduction (H2-TPR), Scanning Electron Microscopy (SEM), and X-ray Photoelectron Spectroscopy (XPS). Catalytic activity was assessed between 600 and 870 °C, at atmospheric pressure and different CH4:O2 molar ratios and Weigh-basis Gas Hourly Space Velocity (WGHSV). It is concluded that low specific surface area values, the existence of surface moderate basic sites, increased concentration of oxygen vacancies and the presence of electrophilic oxygen species (O2 – and O2 2–) on the catalyst surface had a crucial role on the improvement of the catalytic performance in terms of the desirable products, mainly ethylene. It is noted that the addition of Li changed thoroughly the reaction pathway and the products’ distribution, with the C2 selectivity values exceeding 85%. The Li/Mg-Ce catalyst, presenting the higher population of intermediate basic sites and surface superoxide species, showed an improved catalytic activity in terms of XCH4 and production of ethylene, while the incorporation of La3+ into the crystal structure of CeO2 suppressed the production of ethylene. Finally, smaller CH4:O2 molar ratios suppressed the production of hydrocarbons, while enhanced residence times, favoured the dehydrogenation of C2H6 to C2H4. Keywords Cerium-doped catalysts Oxidative coupling of methane Surface oxygen species C2 production 1 Introduction Biomethane, derived from the anaerobic digestion of biomass, is a versatile fuel that can be applied to several end uses, similar to that of natural gas. This is why the terms Renewable Natural Gas (RNG) and Substituted Natural Gas (SNG) are also commonly used to describe this renewable product [1]. A process worthy of investigation is the oxidative dimerization, or coupling of methane (OCM), as it directly converts CH4 for the production of C2 hydrocarbons, particularly ethylene, which is used as a building block material in the petrochemical industry for the production of polymers (e.g., polyethylene) and many other commodity products [2–6]. Notably, the direct conversion of methane to chemicals and fuels is often referred to as the "Holy Grail" of chemistry and catalysis in the twenty-first century [7,8]. This is because the chemical durability of CH4 and the thermodynamically favorable production of CO and CO2 make the production of C2 during the OCM process, extremely complicated [9–13]. The OCM process is an exothermic reaction between CH4 and O2 that usually takes place catalytically between 700 and 900 °C, as reported in the seminal work of Keller and Basin [14], via a heterogeneous - homogeneous mechanism, forming C2 hydrocarbons (e.g., C2H4 or C2H6), H2O, and heat, through the following reactions Eqs. (1) and ((2)). At the same time, undesirable side reactions involving methane, ethane and ethylene oxidation towards CO and CO2 depress the C2-selectivity of the system Eqs. (3)–((5)) [15,16]. (1) C H 4 + 1 2 O 2 → 1 2 C 2 H 4 + H 2 O , Δ H 800 ∘ C = − 139 k J / mol (2) C H 4 + 1 4 O 2 → 1 2 C 2 H 6 + 1 2 H 2 O , Δ H 800 ∘ C = − 87 k J / mol (3) C H 4 + O 2 → C O 2 ( + C O ) + H 2 O (4) C 2 H 6 + O 2 → C O 2 ( + C O ) + H 2 O (5) C 2 H 4 + O 2 → C O 2 ( + C O ) + H 2 O The reaction mechanism is thought to follow four steps: (i) the dissociative or non-dissociative adsorption of oxygen gas on the catalyst surface, (ii) the activation of CH4 on the surface lattice oxygen species by hydrogen abstraction to form a methyl radical (CH3 .) intermediate product, (iii) the coupling of methyl radicals in the gas phase to produce C2H6, and (iv) the dehydrogenation of ethane by surface oxygen species to form ethylene [17]. It is noted that the yield of the desirable C2 hydrocarbons is adversely affected by non-selective reactions of the methyl radicals or the C2 hydrocarbons produced Eqs. (3)–((5)), which enhance the undesirable production of carbon dioxide, carbon monoxide and solid carbon on the catalyst surface [18]. Alkali, alkaline earth and rare earth metal oxides in simple or mixed oxidized form have been used as catalysts for the reaction of OCM [19–23]. There is agreement in the literature that catalytic activity is favored on materials with low specific surface areas, increased number of basic sites and improved availability of surface oxygen vacancies and/or oxygen defects [24]. Catalyst surface oxygen species of interest in the OCM reaction include carbonate species (CO3 2–), lattice oxygen (O2–), superoxide (O2 –) and peroxide species (O2 2–) and hydroxide OH– ions [25–28]. In particular, Zhang et al. [25] reported that for a highly efficient catalyst for the OCM reaction, the surface basic sites and lattice oxygen species are required to adsorb and dissociate CH4 molecules into CH3 ., which in a second step will be coupled to C2H6 and further into C2H4 via a dehydrogenation process. On the other hand, Xu et al. [29], using a La2Ce1.5Ca0.5O7 catalyst, concluded that the selective production of C2 hydrocarbons depends on the electrophilic oxygen species (superoxide and peroxide anions) on the catalyst surface and on the intermediate basic sites. Moreover, Ferreira et al. [28], investigating the effect of Mg2+, Ca2+, and Sr2+ on CeO2 on the OCM reaction, proved that the catalytic samples with the higher amount of surface electrophilic oxygen species showed increased C2H4 and C2H6 selectivity at higher reaction temperature. It is worth noting here that significant research attention has been given to the modification of the OCM catalysts with lithium ions. Lunsford [30] used lithium catalysts based on MgO and found that they presented a reaction mechanism in which the surface defects of Li+O– take part in the chemical reaction as the main active sites, reinforcing the selective production of C2H4 and C2H6. Moreover, Kwon et al. [13] reported that the incorporation of lithium ions into the structure of LaAlO3 caused the formation of the La2Li0.5Al0.5O4 phase, which presented higher catalytic performance than the LaAlO3. In particular, during stability tests that lasted for 10 h, the values of C2 selectivity and yield were increased by almost 40%. It is also important to emphasize that as the reaction takes place at high temperatures, it is beneficial to use catalytic systems with ordered porous structures [31]. In particular, Zhou et al. [32] reported that catalytic samples with advanced textural properties can suppress the effect of pressure drop in the reactor, simultaneously improve the diffusion of reagents and products during the reaction, as well as, favor the heat transfer to the catalyst. Usually, catalytic samples with ordered mesopore and macropore structures exhibit enhanced catalytic performance at intermediate and low reaction temperature in oxidation processes, which can be attributed to the increased availability of surface oxygen species and surface oxygen vacancy sites in the porous structures [33–35]. As is well understood, cerium-based mixed oxides present numerous advantageous properties, as supporting material, such as: (i) excellent redox properties due to the facile reduction of Ce4+ to Ce3+, which can be associated with the genesis of oxygen vacancy sites into the lattice of the crystalline structure [36–38], and (ii) increased surface basicity [39–42]. These are crucial physicochemical characteristics for the process of OCM. Moreover, the incorporation of redox-active basic ions (La3+, Sm3+, Pr3+, Sr2+) into the crystal lattice of CeO2 can improve its thermal stability, enhance its physicochemical properties, and affect the catalytic performance and stability. As a result, La-Ce-O [43], Ce-Pr-O [44], Ce-Zn-O [45], Ce-W-O [46] Ni-La2O3-CeO2/SBA-15 [47], Ni/Pr-Ce [41], Ni/ La-Sm-Ce-O [48], and Al-Ce-Zr-O [37,49] have been used as catalysts in a wide range of processes, such as CO oxidation, methane oxidative coupling, glycerol steam reforming, methane dry reforming and the CO2 methanation reaction. For the work presented herein, we report on the OCM performance of Li-free and Li-doped CeO2 and CeO2 modified with Mg2+ and La3+ catalysts. The supporting materials employed were Ce, Mg-Ce and La-Mg-Ce metal oxides. These were synthesized by means of the microwave assisted sol-gel method. We chose this technique as it can help achieve a high degree of homogeneity even in systems with complex composition, and also to obtain particles with high surface energy and reactivity [42]. This is the first time that this specific preparation method has been applied for materials used in the reaction of OCM. Moreover, lithium ions were added onto the as prepared metal oxides, following the wet impregnation method, to further affect their physicochemical properties, activity and selectivity, in terms of the desirable hydrocarbon products (C2H4 and C2H6). The materials were characterized towards their textural, structural and redox properties, surface basicity, and surface morphology using N2 adsorption-desorption, X-ray diffraction (XRD), Raman spectroscopy, CO2 temperature programmed desorption (CO2-TPD), H2 temperature programmed reduction (H2-TPR) and X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) and Scanning electron microscopy (SEM). The catalytic performance is critically discussed based on the findings of the characterization studies. 2 Materials and methods 2.1 Catalyst synthesis Supporting materials CeO2, and Mg- and La-modified MgOx-CeO2 and La2O3-MgOx-CeO2 mixed oxide supports were synthesized using a microwave assisted sol-gel method. The microwave reactor was described in detail in a previous study [41]. The precursor salts Ce(NO3)3.6H2O (Aldrich, 99.95%), Mg(NO3)2 6H2O (Aldrich, 99.95%) and La(NO3)3.6H2O (Aldrich, 99.95%) were dissolved in a mixture of ethylene glycol and water, while the total metal loading (Mg+Ce or La+Mg+Ce), with nominal molar ratio Mg:Ce = 0.1:0.9 and La:Mg:Ce = 0.05:0.1:0.85, was kept at 0.06 mol in all the synthesized mixed oxides. The materials were then dried in air overnight at 120 °C. Finally, the samples were calcined under atmospheric conditions at 850 °C for 5 h, using a heating ramp of 20 °C min−1, to form the oxide and mixed oxide supporting materials. Li-doped materials The lithium-based catalysts were prepared using the wet impregnation method with the appropriate LiNO3 (BioUltra, ≥ 99.0%) solution. The lithium loading on the catalyst surface was 3 wt.% as this concentration has been reported to favor the formation of desirable products [39]. After impregnation, the slurries obtained were air dried overnight at 120 °C and calcined at 850 °C for 5 h using the above heating ramp; these samples will be denoted on this manuscript as “calcined” samples. The materials are labelled as Ce, Mg-Ce, La-Mg-Ce, Li/Ce, Li/Mg-Ce and Li/La-Mg-Ce catalysts. 2.2 Catalyst characterization The instruments and methodologies followed for the characterization of the materials presented herein are presented in detail in the Supporting Information File accompanying this manuscript. Succinctly, N2 adsorption/desorption measurements were carried out on a high resolution 3Flex (Micromeritics) operated at -196 οC. The total Specific Surface Area (SSA, m2/g) was determined by the multi-point Brunauer-Emmet-Teller (BET) method (0.05 < P/P0 < 0.20), while the Pore Size Distribution (PSD) was estimated by the Barrett-Joyner-Halenda (BJH) method. X-Ray Diffraction (XRD) analysis was carried out on a Rigaku MiniFlex II powder diffractometer, with Cu-Kα1 radiation (1.5416 Å), operated at 30 kV and 20 mA. The identification of the XRD patterns was conducted according to the International Center for Diffraction Data (ICDD) database. Raman spectroscopy was performed on a Witec Alpha 300 apparatus using a 2 nm laser and research grade optical microscope with various lenses. CO2 Temperature-Programmed Desorption (CO2-TPD) measurements were performed using the Autochem 2920 apparatus (Micromeritics). A gas mixture of 5 vol% CO2/Ar was passed over 0.12 g of the calcined catalyst. Desorption was performed under a flow of He with a temperature ramp of 30 °C/min. The Thermal Conductivity Detector (TCD) signal was recorded continuously. H2 Temperature-Programmed Reduction (H2-TPR) experiments were performed using the Autochem 2920 apparatus (Micromeritics) by passing 10 vol% H2/Ar gas mixture over 0.12 g of the calcined catalyst. The temperature ramp was 30 °C/min and the TCD signal was recorded continuously. X-ray Photoelectron Spectroscopy (XPS) analyses were performed on a ThermoFisher Scientific Instruments K-Alpha+ spectrometer. The XPS spectra were acquired using a monochromated Al Kα X-ray source (hν = 1486.6 eV) and an X-ray spot of ∼400 μm radius. Survey spectra were acquired employing a Pass Energy of 200 eV. High resolution, core level spectra for all elements were acquired with a Pass Energy of 50 eV. Electron microscopy analysis was performed in a Scanning Electron Microscope SEM (FEG INSPECT 50). The samples were deposited by a drop-evaporation method in a Si substrate and carbon sputter coated to prevent the specimen charging. 2.3 OCM reaction experiments The OCM reaction was carried out at atmospheric pressure, in a continuous flow, single pass, fixed bed quartz reactor (I.D. = 0.65 cm). For each experiment carried out herein, catalytic activation was undertaken in-situ, at 600 °C, using a flow of a 20% O2/Ar (30 min in total) and the catalytic bed was diluted with quartz glass in a ratio equal to 1. Catalytic performance was studied using three different experimental procedures (termed herein as, protocols #1, #2 and #3). Experimental protocol #1 aimed at investigating the effect of the reaction temperature on CH4 conversion (XCH4, %), CO, CO2 and C2 selectivity (SCOx and SC2, %), C2 yield (YC2, %), and C2H4/C2H6 molar ratio in the temperature range of 600–870 °C. The gas mixture used as feed consisted by 40% CH4, 10% O2 and 50% Ar, corresponding to a molar ratio CH4/O2 = 4/1. The total feed flow rate of the reactor was kept constant at 50 ml min–1, i.e., at a Weight-basis Gas Hourly Space Velocity WGHSV) equal to 10,000 mL g–1 h–1. After the activation process, the temperature of the catalytic bed was retained at 600 °C, the reaction feed was introduced into the reactor and the products of the reaction were recorded. The temperature was further increased stepwise, remaining for 45 min at each step to ensure steady-state conditions. Experimental protocol #2 aimed to investigate the catalytic performance under increased oxygen concentration (CH4/O2 = 3/1).. Moreover, experiments using only the best performing catalyst were carried out at two different WGHSV, 10,000 mL g–1 h–1 and 4000 mL g–1 h–1. Finally, the stability of the best performing catalyst was assessed at 800 °C during a short (8 h) time-on-stream test (experimental protocol #3). For this experiment, the CH4/O2 molar ratio was decreased further to 2.5 and the WGHSV used was equal to 4000 mL g–1 h–1. The OCM products were analyzed using an on-line gas chromatography. The system (GC-Agilent 7890A) is equipped with two columns in parallel, HP-Plot-Q (19095-Q04, 30 m length, 0.530 mm I.D.) and HP-Molesieve (19095P-MSO, 30 m length, 0.530 mm I.D.), and TCD and FID detectors. The GC was appropriately calibrated for the analysis of CH4, C2H6, C2H4, CO, CO2 and H2. Methane conversion (XCH4), C2 selectivity (SC2), COx (= CO + CO2) selectivity (SCOx), C2 yield (YC2), and C2H4/C2H6 molar ratio were calculated using the following equations (Eqs. (6)–(10)): (6) X C H 4 = F C H 4 i n − F C H 4 o u t F C H 4 i n x 100 % (7) S C O x = C C O o u t + C C O 2 o u t C C O o u t + C C O 2 o u t + 2 * C C 2 H 6 o u t + 2 * C C 2 H 4 o u t x 100 % (8) S C 2 = 2 * C C 2 H 6 o u t + 2 * C C 2 H 4 o u t C C O o u t + C C O 2 o u t + 2 * C C 2 H 6 o u t + 2 * C C 2 H 4 o u t x 100 % (9) Y C 2 = X C H 4 * S C 2 100 (10) M o l a r r a t i o = C C 2 H 4 o u t C C 2 H 6 o u t 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Characterization results 3.1.1 N2 physisorption measurements The N2 adsorption – desorption technique was used to investigate the textural properties of each support and each synthesized Li-based catalyst. Regarding the supports (results shown in Fig. 1 a and b), and according to the IUPAC classification [50], all materials present Type III isotherms and Type H3 hysteresis loops. Moreover, from the N2 adsorption/desorption isotherms (Fig. 1a), the increased adsorption at relative pressure P/P0 ≈ 0.8 can be assigned to materials with macropore structures (size > 50 nm), but the pore size distribution curves (pore width = 2–50 nm) reveal materials that also contain mesoporous structures (Fig. 1b). The specific surface area (SSA), pore volume and mean pore size diameter values of the supports and counterpart Li catalysts are shown in Table 1 . As a first observation, the introduction of Mg2+ and the further addition of La3+ onto the structure of CeO2 did not significantly affect the surface area of the corresponding samples, as the SSA (7.8–9.0 m2 g–1) and pore volume (0.04–0.06 cm3 g–1) values are rather similar. According to the literature, the catalysts employed in the reaction of OCM usually present relatively low SSA values in comparison to the typical heterogeneous catalytic systems [11,27,51]. This is because the catalytic surface is only necessary for the adsorption of CH4 and the activation of C-H bond, while the second stage of the OCM reaction, involves the coupling of methyl radical intermediates (CH3·) in the gas phase [52,53]. However, Lomonosov et al. [53], reported that increased SSA values improve the surface side reactions in the OCM process, leading to the deep oxidation of CH4 and of the intermediate products. Regarding the Li-doped catalysts (Table 1), it is obvious that the addition of Li+ ions onto the surface of the Ce, Mg-Ce and La-Mg-Ce supports caused a drastic drop of the SSA values. This finding agrees with results presented in the literature [54] and is caused by the blocking of the internal pores structure in the Ce, Mg-Ce and La-Mg-Ce supporting materials by Li species. Tang et al. [55] reported that this drop can be assigned to the high temperature of the calcination procedure, which favors the decomposition of the deposited Li salts, forming the desirable Li+O– surface active sites for the OCM reaction. However, increased mobility of Li-species on the surface of the supporting material, making them forming island type of aggregates and blocking the internal pores structure of the supports, is also possible [56]. 3.1.2 X-ray diffraction analysis XRD analysis was conducted in order to investigate the structural changes to the calcined samples caused by the addition of dopants (Mg2+, La3+) as well as of Li+ onto the crystal structure of CeO2. As can be seen in Fig. 2 , the XRD patterns for all materials used herein clearly present numerous sharp diffraction peaks, at 2θ of 28.73o, 33.32o, 47.64o, 56.56o, and 59.32o, corresponding to the planes (111), (200), (220), (311) and (222), respectively, which are attributed to the polycrystalline fluorite structure of CeO2 (JCPDS card no: 96-900-9009). It is important to note that the highest diffraction peak (most predominant one) at 2θ = 28.73o shows a major shift to lower 2θ angles for the La-Mg-Ce (28.60o) in comparison to pure CeO2 and Mg-Ce supports (Fig. 2c) (28.69o). Similar shift to lower angles can be noticed for the rest of the planes as we move from CeO2 to Mg-Ce to La-Mg-Ce. For instance, for the (200) plane, a shift from the 33.32o to 33.24o to 33.17° can be observed as we move from CeO2 to Mg-Ce to La-Mg-Ce oxide (support) composition. For the (220) plane the shift is from 47.64 to 47.62 to 47.54o, respectively. For the (311) plane, the shift is from 56.56o to 56.48o to 56.34o, respectively. For the (222) plane, the shift is from 59.32o, to 59.32o to 59.09o, respectively. The same finding was observed for the corresponding Li-based sample (i.e., Li/La-Mg-Ce). This structural behavior is attributed to the successful incorporation of the La3+ ions (ionic radius of 1.10 Å) into the crystal lattice of CeO2 (Ce4+ ionic radius 0.97 Å), leading to the formation of a La-Ce-O mixed oxide with unknown composition (not the nominal) [48,57]. Moreover, as is well understood, the substitution of alio-valent cations (e.g., La3+) into the crystalline structure of CeO2 is also related to the formation of oxygen vacancy sites, which can host adsorbed electrophilic oxygen species [40–42,48]. On the other hand, for the Mg-Ce sample, the minor shift to lower angles can be attributed to the interstitial placement of Mg2+ into ceria lattice and not the substitution of Ce4+ by Mg2+ ions. This is expected based on the different MgO symmetry in its crystal structure. The absence of peaks corresponding to MgO or MgCO3 implies either very small crystallite size (< 4 nm) or amorphous phases [41]. The crystallite size of CeO2 was calculated using the Scherrer formula based on the strongest (111) reflection peak at 28.6o (Table 1). For the La-Mg-Ce this value stood at 21.4 nm and for the Mg-Ce at 34.9 nm, both lower than pure CeO2, which was 43.9 nm. In the case of the La-Mg-Ce support, the higher decrease of the crystallite size is the result of the combination of a solid solution (La-Ce-O) and a separate phase, MgO, formation; the competition of the two phases lead to the smaller Ce-based crystallite size. The decrease of the crystallite size for the Mg-Ce sample can be assigned to the possible formation of a separate MgO or MgCO3 crystal phase on the catalyst surface, which act in competition with CeO2, decreasing its crystallite size. Focusing now on the Li-based catalysts (Fig. 2b and d), it should be first mentioned that no diffraction peaks of Li2O species were found. This could have been an indication that these particles are highly dispersed onto the support however, the appearance of three small diffraction peaks at 2θ of 21.2o, 30.3o and 31.7o, which correspond to the formation of LiCO3 (JCPDS card no: 87–0729), seems a more plausible explanation for this absence. LiCO3 is generated by the reaction between Li2O and CO2 in air, at room temperature [58]. However, in the case of Li/Mg-Ce and Li/La-Mg-Ce, the similar ionic radius of Li+ (0.76 Å) and Mg2+ (0.72 Å) and the increased calcination temperature may also lead to the incorporation of Li+ into the crystal lattice of the secondary phase MgO, forming some surface defect centers [Li+O–]. As mentioned above, Tang et al. argued that the existence of such defect centers would be important for catalytic performance, as active sites in the OCM reaction [55]. However, Schwach et al. [59] reported that Li+ ions act as a structural promoter of MgO favoring the formation of terminating higher index planes such as (111) on the MgO support. Furthermore, they reported that these planes were responsible for the selective production of C2 products. Lima-Correa et al. [60] reported that the substitution of divalent ions by monovalent ions led to the formation of O2– ions into the structure of MgO, increasing the basic strength of the support. Finally, for the Li-based catalysts, it is interesting to note that regarding the crystallite size of CeO2 (Table 1), a significant increase of the crystallite size can be observed, which is more pronounced for the Li/Ce catalyst. This finding can be assigned to the possible melting of Li species on the catalyst surface, which agrees with the results of the BET analysis, leading to lower SSA values and the formation of larger crystallites of CeO2. 3.1.3 Raman analysis Fig. 3 depicts the Raman spectra obtained for the supporting materials (Fig. 3a) and for the Li-based catalysts (Fig. 3b, c and d); the spectra presented correspond to the samples obtained after calcination at 850 °C. Raman spectroscopy has the potential to provide crucial information about the state of oxides formed, the oxygen chemical environment, as well as the possible formation of oxygen vacancy sites [48]. Regarding the Raman spectra obtained over the supporting materials (Fig. 3a), the strongest intensity peak at ∼461 cm–1 is attributed to the F2g mode, which is assigned to the stretching vibrations of the O2– around the Ce4+ ions in the CeO8 octahedra [61]. However, differences between pure ceria and the promoted supporting materials can be observed. Firstly, the addition of the promoters (La3+ and/or Mg2+) caused a decrease in the intensity of this peak (more obvious in the case of La-Mg-Ce support). Secondly, the addition of La3+ ions caused a significant red shift (moving to lower wavenumber) from 461 cm−1 to 451 cm−1 for the La-Mg-Ce support, as a consequence of the incorporation of the La3+ ions into the cubic fluorite CeO2 crystalline structure and the disturbance of the oxygen symmetry, forming a La-Ce-O solid oxide solution [62], which is in agreement with the results obtained by the XRD analysis. Another region where attention should focus is between 540 and 650 cm–1, as it can provide valuable information about the defects and particularly oxygen vacancy sites [63,64]. However, the lack of clear band on the spectra presented herein in this region does not allow us to draw a solid conclusion regarding the defects/oxygen vacancies (595 cm–1). Possible reason for the vanishing of the bands can be the high temperature of calcination (850°C), which may have caused partial annihilation of the defects. Graham et al. [65] and Weber et al. [66] reported that the F2g band is sensitive in the oxygen stoichiometry (CeO2-x) and this is an indirect way to probe the change of the oxygen content and thus Ov in the oxide. Lee at al. [67] also reported that the F2g band shift is linked to the oxygen stoichiometry. Examining now the Li-based catalysts (Fig. 3b, c and d), an argument can be made that the addition of Li+ ions caused the following changes in the structure, with particular focus on the defects and oxygen vacancies and oxygen species, as discussed herein: (a) formation of new band at the region < 300 cm–1 due to the relaxation of Raman selection rules and the defects generated. (b) the defects region in the 500–650 cm–1 can now be seen clearly and can be ascribed to Ov and LaO8 defects and impurities. (c) O2 2– peroxo and O2 – superoxo species are oxygen intermediates that are involved in the process of CeO2-x (sub-stoichiometric) transformation to CeO2. Raman spectroscopy is good probing tool for such species due to their O=O covalent bond. In particular, ν(O=O) stretching vibrations of peroxo and superoxo species can be found from the bands in the 800–900 cm–1 and 1100−1200 cm–1 ranges, respectively [68]. The genesis of surface electrophilic oxygen species can also be deduced by the minor peak observed at ≈ 1082 cm–1, which corresponds to surface superoxide (O2 −) species [25]. Petrolini et al. [31] reported that oxides with low valence atoms in the structure present improved oxidative properties, due to the formation of electrophilic oxygen species on the surface. The role of the specific electrophilic oxygen species in the reaction of OCM is crucial, as it is widely accepted that they are important active sites for the OCM reaction and the selective production of C2H4 [25,29]. 3.1.4 Surface basic properties CO2 temperature programmed desorption experiments (Fig. 4 a and b) were performed for all prepared samples after pretreatment in oxygen atmosphere. The aim was to investigate the nature and strength of the surface basic sites. It is worth mentioning that the CO2 desorption area is analogous to the population of the surface basic sites. According to the literature [69], the surface basicity can be categorized into three areas in terms of CO2-desorption temperature, corresponding to three types of basic sites with different strength. Thus, the CO2 desorption peaks below 300 °C, between 300 and 550 °C and at temperatures higher than 550 °C can be assigned to low strength, moderate, and high strength basic sites, respectively. It is noted that there is a strong relation between surface basicity and the surface oxygen anions (O2 –, O2 2– and O–) and electrophilic defects on the catalyst surface [70]. As can be observed from Fig. 4, the addition of Li+ ions onto the supporting materials led to a redistribution of the surface basic sites. Comparing the profiles of the Li-based catalytic samples, Li/Mg-Ce presents a much larger CO2 desorption peak at the intermediate temperature range. On the other hand, the Li promoted CeO2 catalyst exhibits the highest population of weak and strong basic sites. Nagamoto et al. [71] studying the reaction of methane oxidation showed that the basic properties of the catalyst may be attributed to the surface oxygen anions (O2 −, O2 2−, and O2−). Moreover, Wang et al. [72] reported that all types of basic sites favor the activation of CH4 molecules, however, the basic sites with moderate strength are beneficial for the selective production of C2H4 and C2H6, while the weak basic sites favor the production of CO2 and CO. In addition, Zhang et al. [25] noted that the formation of intermediate basic sites is related to the presence of surface electrophilic oxygen species. Thus, it is crucial to add into the catalyst structure suitable promoters in order to generate the appropriate active sites (peroxide and superoxide) for the OCM reaction. From the CO2-TPD results presented herein, it can be argued that the addition of Mg2+ dopant and Li+ promoter ions onto the structure of CeO2 modified the way that CO2 interacts with the surface, creating active sites for the desirable production of C2 coupling products, mainly ethylene as it will be discussed in a later section. 3.1.5 Reduction properties The redox properties of the catalytic materials were studied using H2-TPR. It is important to note at this point that the reducibility of the Li-containing materials was not investigated due to the possible formation of metallic Li species, which could damage the quartz reactor and the catalyst surface due to the very low melting point of Li. Thus, the analysis of the redox characteristics was focused only on the supporting materials (Ce, Mg-Ce and La-Mg-Ce). As shown in Fig. 5 , the cerium oxide support presents three main reduction peaks, in agreement with the available literature [73]. In particular, the reduction peaks between 400 and 550 °C can be attributed to the reduction of Ce4+ to Ce3+, together with the creation of oxygen vacancies. The peak at higher temperature (T > 700°C) can be assigned to the reduction of the bulk oxygen (O2–) of CeO2 [41,42]. On the other hand, the promoted Mg-Ce and La-Mg-Ce mixed oxide supports showed peaks of H2 consumption lower than 400 °C. Thus, the introduction of these promoters (Mg2+ and/or La3+) led to the reduction of CeO2 at lower temperatures due to the presence of more active surface oxygen species, including both surface lattice oxygen and chemically adsorbed oxygen species [74]. Also, as it was proved earlier, the promoted Mg-Ce and La-Mg-Ce exhibit smaller crystallite size and thus it is anticipated that their reduction profile is shifted to lower temperature. This is a desirable property as it can lead to the production of C2H4 and C2H6 at lower reaction temperature. Papa et al. [70] reported that the plethora, type, and activity of the surface oxygen species are crucial factors for the OCM reaction. 3.1.6 Surface oxygen species Fig. 6 shows peak fitted O 1s XPS spectra obtained for the calcined Li based catalysts and corresponding supports. As can be observed in Fig. 6a, the XPS spectra of the catalyst supports (Ce, Mg-Ce and La-Mg-Ce) show two overlapping O 1s peaks. In particular, the larger peak at ≈ 529.0 eV can be attributed to the presence of surface lattice O2– species, while the lower intensity peak at ≈ 532.0 eV can be attributed to surface hydroxide/carbonate compounds [75,76]. To corroborate the formation of carbonate species, the C 1s peaks are shown in the Supporting information (Fig. S1). The carbonate peak appears at a binding energy of ≈ 289 eV in addition to the adventitious carbon at 285.0 eV [55,77]. It is clear that the intensity of the carbonate peak is much higher for the Li catalysts than the supports. Quantification of the O/C ratio for the O 1s and C 1s ‘carbonate’ peaks yield values of between 5 and 7, whereas a value of 3 would be expected for CO3 2– species. This excess of O strongly indicates that the O 1s component at ≈ 532.0 eV is comprised of not just carbonate species, but also hydroxide species. A third oxygen peak, at a binding energy of ≈ 533 eV, is also present in the O 1s spectra. A peak at this energy for metal oxide surfaces is typically indicative of adsorbed water. However, a peak is also known to occur around this binding energy associated with the presence of oxygen vacancies. Since oxygen vacancies have been identified in the Raman spectra, the presence of such vacancies could be contributing to this peak. Additionally, the presence of superoxide species has also been observed in the Raman spectra (Fig. 3 (d)) and Zhang et al. [25] have indicated that such superoxide species also give rise to a peak at ≈ 533 eV. So, there are multiple possible origins of this small high binding energy O peak. For the calcined supports, compared to CeO2, the observed increase in the hydroxide/carbonate peak for the Mg-Ce and La-Mg-Ce supports is not surprising, as these species increase the basicity of the oxide. However, the addition of Li strongly increases the intensity of this hydroxide/carbonate peak. Again, the basicity has been increased from this addition and Li is known to be highly reactive in atmospheric environments. Ismail et al. [78] have shown that the native surface layer formed on Li is comprised of an outer Li2CO3/LiOH layer and inner Li2O layer. The addition of Li has also been shown to result in the formation of surface electrophilic oxygen species (O2 –), identified by the small peak at 1082 cm–1 the Raman analysis (Fig. 3 (d)). Considering the ≈ 533 eV peak, it can be seen in Table 2 that the intensity of this peak is generally higher for the Li catalysts compared to the supports. Furthermore, considering the intensity ratio of the ≈ 533 eV peak to the lattice oxygen peak, the peak intensity ratio is substantially higher for the Li based catalysts than for the supports. In both cases (i.e., the ≈ 533 eV peak intensity relative to the total O concentration or lattice oxygen concentration), the progressive order of the peak intensity ratios for the Li catalysts is Li/Mg-Ce > Li/La-Mg-Ce > Li/Ce. Although caution should be taken with over-interpretation due to the multiple possible contributions to this ≈ 533 eV peak, it is interesting to note the progression in these peak intensity ratios, as the higher ratios can be correlated with increased ethylene production (discussed below) [20,79]. As mentioned above, in the OCM process, surface lattice oxygen species improve the undesirable reaction of strong oxidation of CH4, increasing the selective production of CO and CO2 [25,29]. Thus, the relative concentrations (%) of surface lattice O2– species were calculated from the area under the corresponding peak (≈ 529.0 eV) and the results presented in Table 2. As can be observed, for the calcined supports, the La-Mg-Ce sample gives the lowest concentration, 68.3%, of lattice oxygen, while the Ce and Mg-Ce samples exhibit concentrations of 80.7 and 70.9%, respectively. Turning our attention now to the CO3 2– species, which can improve the production of C2 by acting as additional OCM active sites (promoting the creation of Ο2 2– species) [28], from Table 2 it can be seen that the addition of Mg2+ and La3+ led to an increase in the surface concentration of carbonates. The peaks corresponding to Ce 3d are presented in Fig. S2, for all materials used in the present study. The peaks are labelled as v and u, corresponding to Ce 3d5/2 and Ce 3d3/2 transitions, respectively. The main peaks are v, v’’, v’’’, u, u’’, u’’’ corresponding to Ce4+ species, with peaks labelled as v’ and u’ corresponding to Ce3+ species. From the results presented herein, the samples consist mainly of Ce4+ (CeO2), in corroboration with the Raman and XRD analysis. Ferreira et al. [76] reported that the number of the electrophilic oxygen species are related to the presence of Ce3+ species on the catalyst surface. The XPS Mg 1s peak is shown in Fig. S3. For the supporting materials, the Mg 1s exhibits a peak at binding energy of 1305.3 eV, which can be attributed to MgCO3 [80]. For the Li-based catalysts, the Mg 1s exhibits a peak at ≈1304.5 eV, which indicates the presence of MgO/Mg(OH)2 [80]. The La 3d XPS spectra for the La-Mg-Ce and Li/La-Mg-Ce sample are presented in Fig. S4. As can be observed, there are two double peaks corresponding to La 3d3/2 and La 3d5/2 with binding energies and peak shapes in good agreement with those of La3+ [81]. Table 3 summarizes the surface concentration of each element. As can be observed, the concentration of carbon for the supporting materials is very low (6–8%), but higher on the Li-based samples (16–18%), due to the presence of surface carbonate species. The concentration of La is lower than expected, at around 2.0 at.%, while that of Mg is approximately equal to the nominal value (≈ 10 at.%). The high Li concentration (28–32 at.%) is associated with its particularly high affinity for O species, thus its preferential diffusion to the surface to form Li(OH)2/Li2(CO)3. 3.2 Catalytic activity 3.2.1 OCM performance of the supporting materials The OCM performance of the calcined Ce, Mg-Ce and La-Mg-Ce supports was investigated between 600 and 850 °C, with the results presented in Table S1 (supporting information). As can be observed, all the supporting materials showed low catalytic activity and low C2 selectivity and yield for the whole temperature range, promoting the undesirable total combustion of CH4 and/or the combustion of the methyl radicals produced during the reaction. Consequently, the production of CO and CO2 increases with increasing temperature. The La-Mg-Ce support showed the highest values for C2 selectivity, for the entire temperature range under investigation (600–850 °C), indicating that the addition of La3+ into the crystalline structure of CeO2 generated active sites for the reaction of OCM. This is in agreement with the Raman analysis for the supporting materials (Fig. 3a) presented above, which show that La3+ ions incorporated into the cubic fluorite structure of CeO2 helped develop oxygen vacancy sites due to the formation of La-Ce-O solid solution. However, for all reaction temperature (600, 650, 700, 750, 800 and 850 °C), the addition of La3+ led also to a decrease in CH4 conversion (retaining nonetheless the C2 yield values slightly higher than the other supporting materials). The lower conversion of methane shown by the La-Mg-Ce can be attributed to the lower number of basic sites (CO2-TPD; Fig. 4) [82]. The higher values for C2 selectivity for the La-Ce-Mg sample may be attributed to the increased amount of carbonates species (24.2%) and the lower concentration (68.3%) of the lattice oxygen species (XPS analysis, presented in Table 2), which suppressed the total oxidation of CH4 or methyl radicals produced, improving the selective production of C2H6, and as a second step, the dehydrogenation of C2H6 to ethylene [83]. 3.2.2 OCM performance of the counterpart Li-based catalysts The OCM performance of the Li/Ce, Li/Mg-Ce and Li/La-Mg-Ce was investigated between 600 and 870 °C. The results are presented in Fig. 7 (a–d) in terms of XCH4, SC2, SCOx, and YC2 as well as C2H4/C2H6 molar ratio. As a first observation, the addition of Li changed the reaction pathway and the products distribution, improving the production of hydrocarbons (C2H4 and C2H6). As discussed earlier, and based on the Raman and XPS results, the addition of Li+ ions caused the formation of peroxide species (O2 2–) superoxide species (O2 –) and oxygen vacancies and defects, which act as active sites for the selective production of hydrocarbons [23]. However, a decrease in the conversion of CH4, in comparison with the non-Li containing supports, can also be observed, behavior that has already been reported in the literature [84]. Among the Li-based catalysts, the highest value for CH4 conversion was achieved using the Li/Mg-Ce sample, at almost 15%, at 870 °C (Fig. 7a). It can be argued that the simultaneous presence of intermediate (moderate strength) basic sites (CO2-TPD) and the electrophilic oxygen species (O2 2–, O2 –) (Raman) of the Li/Mg-Ce sample are the reason for this enhanced performance in terms of XCH4. Regarding C2 selectivity (Fig. 7b), at temperature lower than ≈ 750 °C, all Li-based materials showed similar values, which exceeded 85% (at 750 °C). At higher temperature, and for the Li/Ce and Li/Mg-Ce in particular, C2 selectivity decreased due to the higher production of CO via the undesirable reaction of the total oxidation of CH4 [19]. On the other hand, over 720 °C, the Li/La-Mg-Ce catalyst favored the formation of C2H4 and C2H6, probably due to the desirable active sites formed on the catalyst surface. It is also interesting to note that the production of C2H4 improved also for the Li/Mg-Ce at the highest temperatures (over 850 °C). Specifically, the C2H4/C2H6 ratio increase from 0.30 (850 °C) to 0.78 (870 °C) for the Li/Mg-Ce and from 0.25 (850 °C) to 0.44 (870°C) for the Li/La-Mg-Ce. For Li/Ce, production of C2H4 was achieved only at 870 °C. The increase recorded is probably a result of the reinforcement of the dehydrogenation of ethane to ethylene. These results are in agreement with the available literature. For example, Yoon et al. [17] reported that the surface lattice oxygen species have a crucial role in ethylene production, as they are active sites for the dehydrogenation of C2H6 to ethylene. Cheng et al. [85] studied the catalytic performance of Li-Mg6MnO8 in the chemical looping oxidative coupling of methane, and argued that the Li ions influenced the formation of surface oxygen vacancy sites, decreased the adsorption energy of the intermediates methyl radicals and improved the activation of methane's C-H bond, increasing the selectivity to C2 products. 3.2.3 Influence of the CH4/O2 molar ratio on OCM performance The performance of the Li-based catalysts was also investigated using more severe reaction conditions (i.e., lower CH4/O2 molar ratio); the results are presented in Fig. 8 (a–d). As can be seen, the reduction of the CH4/O2 ratio led to a sharp decline in C2 selectivity, mainly at higher reaction temperatures, but also, to an increase in the XCH4 values. These results are in agreement with published literature [55]. This catalytic behavior is caused by the reaction between the methyl radicals produced during the reaction and O2, which is in higher concentrations in the gas stream, leading to lower yield of C2 and to an increase in COx production, with carbon monoxide being the main by-product. Fig. 8(a–c), shows that the Li/La-Mg-Ce presented higher catalytic activity in comparison to the other two samples. In particular, in terms of the selectivity of the desirable products, the largest differences were recorded at 800 °C, where SC2 follows the order: 57% (Li/Mg-Ce) < 68% (Li/Ce) < 84% (Li/La-Mg-Ce). Interestingly, as can be seen in Fig. 8d, the higher concentration of O2 in the OCM reaction feedstock seems to have strongly strengthened the production of C2H4 through the dehydrogenation of the initially formed C2H6, achieving C2H4/C2H6 values for the Li/Mg-Ce catalyst equal to 1.8 at 870 °C. 3.2.4 Influence of reactants’ contact time on OCM performance As the contact time between the reactants (CH4 and O2) and catalytic surface has an important role in the reaction of OCM [86], additional experiments were performed at a WGHSV equal to 4000 mL g–1 h–1, i.e., lower than the 10,000 mL g–1 h–1 previously used. The experiments were carried out using only the Li/La-Mg-Ce, because this material showed the highest SC2 when the CH4/O2 molar ratio was equal to 3 (Fig. 8). The results obtained are presented in Table S2. Table S2 makes clear that at high WGHSV the production of C2H4 and C2H6 is favored, as C2 selectivity exceeds 85% at intermediate reaction temperature. The decrease in C2 selectivity observed at T > 760 °C, with an increase in the contact time, is caused by the reinforcement of the undesirable production of COx. However, when examining the C2H4/C2H6 ratio it seems that the increased residence time led to an improvement in the production of C2H4. 3.2.5 Catalytic stability The stability of the Li/La-Mg-Ce sample was investigated at 800 °C for 8 h. As shown in Fig. 9 a, the catalyst seems to lose quite sharply its ability to convert CH4 during the first hour of the reaction, (loss of about 25% of its initial activity), but it then obtains a rather stable performance. This decrease in CH4 conversion is accompanied by an increase in the production of olefins and paraffins due to the suppression of the undesirable production of COx (Fig. 9b). However, even though the C2 selectivity increased, the C2H4/C2H6 molar ratio decreased continuously with time (Fig. 9c). According to the available literature [13,87–89], the main reason for the deactivation of Li-based samples is the loss of Li species from the catalyst surface due to vaporization in an oxygen atmosphere or by the diffusion of Li+ species onto the walls of the quartz reactor, forming the Li2SiO3 compound. 3.3 Impact of physicochemical properties on catalytic performance As is well understood, catalytic performance in the OCM reaction is a combination of different important factors, including specific surface area, acid/base properties, oxygen vacancies availability, surface oxygen species (lattice and/or electrophilic oxygen species) and the possible interaction between Li species and the supporting materials, which can generate additional active sites for the activation of CH4 and as second step the production of ethane and then ethylene. Each of these will be briefly reviewed below. Porosity: In regards to the specific surface area, literature reports [52,53,70,90] that low values are desirable, as the activation of CH4 towards the production of methyl radical intermediates, which then couple in the gas phase, seems to be favored. Moreover, it has been argued that materials with large specific surface area accelerate the side reactions and lead to the production of CO and CO2, the main reactions that take place on the catalyst surface [51]. All the herein materials are of low surface area (0.2–8.6 m2 g–1). Surface basicity: In terms of the acid/base properties, moderate basic sites, acting synergistically with the available oxygen species, enhance activity and selectivity. For example, Xu et al. [82] showed that the stronger surface basic sites of Ln2Ce2O7 (Ln= La, Sm, Y and Pr) in comparison with pure CeO2 were beneficial to the reaction of OCM. Fang et al. [23], using Ln2Zr2O7 compounds (Ln = La, Pr, Sm, Y), concluded that the incorporation of La3+ into the crystal structure of CeO2 caused a strong increase in the population of the moderate basic sites, which reinforced the catalytic activity and selectivity towards C2 hydrocarbons. This was confirmed by Papa et al. [70] using turnover frequency (TOF) experiments. Specifically, the authors proved that the surface basic sites play a key role for the adsorption and activation of methane (formation of CH3-Mg2+/Ce3+/La3+-OH species) to produce C2 hydrocarbons, and that surface acidity is responsible for the undesirable combustion of CH4 to CO2 and CO. Thus, doping with La3+, Mg2+ or Li+ can create surface basic sites of different types, strength, and location on the catalyst surface (e.g., edges, corners, kinks). Based on the CO2-TPD experiments presented herein, the addition of Li+ caused the redistribution of the basic sites on the catalyst surface. Also, the presence of MgO or MgCO3 species seems to improve the basic character of the corresponding samples. The Li/Mg-Ce catalyst in particular presented the higher population of intermediate basic sites; crucial factor for the acceleration of CH4 conversion and the selective production of ethylene, while the Li/Ce catalyst presented the higher number of weak basic sites, which contribute to low conversion of CH4 and the lower production of C2 hydrocarbons [70]. Oxygen species: Catalytic activity and selectivity are also strongly influenced by the availability of oxygen vacancies and the type of surface oxygen species produced. Additional oxygen vacancy sites can be created by modifying the supporting material (e.g., by the incorporation of La3+ into the structure of Ce4+). Moreover, OCM has the ability to replenish the oxygen vacancies on the catalyst surface by the release of water or COx after the activation of methane [91]. Importantly, during the OCM process the oxygen of the gas phase is adsorbed on the created oxygen vacancies of the catalyst surface, resulting in the genesis (and subsequent regeneration for the next catalytic cycle) of electrophilic oxygen species (O2 −, O2 2−) [92–94]. It is noted that there is no clear consensus in the literature over the role of electrophilic oxyanions on the C2 selectivity. For example, Schwach et al. [95] reported that the superoxide species reinforce the deep oxidation of methane producing CO and CO2, an argument that was also made by other research studies [96,97]. However, numerous other studies have argued that the surface peroxide and superoxide species are crucial active sites for the selective production of C2H6 and C2H4. In particular, Kwon et al. [13] argued that the improved catalytic activity of a La2Li0.5Al0.5O4 catalyst can be attributed to the abundance of electrophilic lattice oxygen species, and assigned the selective production of COx to the nucleophilic lattice oxygen species (Olat(n)). Moreover, Kim et. al. [15] studied the influence of the surface oxygen species (electrophilic, moderate, and nucleophilic lattice oxygen species) on different catalytic systems and reported that the electrophilic surface lattice oxygen on the LaAlO3 catalyst favored the production of C2H6 and C2H4. In addition, the authors proved that the oxygen from the gas-phase participates in the catalytic cycle via its adsorption into the oxygen vacancies. As is well understood, the electrophilic character of the selective oxygen species is affected by the doping of the supporting materials with alkali or rare earth metals. In particular, Cho et al. [98] studying the catalytic activity of MgO catalysts and the effect of the use of calcium ions as a promoter, reported that the incorporation of Ca2+ into the structure of MgO formed oxygen vacancy sites and influenced the basic properties of the catalytic sample. Moreover, they showed that the formed oxygen vacancies increased the production of methyl radicals via the adsorption and activation of CH4, while the surface lattice oxygen species with medium basicity (O2 2–, O2 –) played a key role in the dehydrogenation of C2H6, producing C2H4 which is a more valuable product. Additionally, it has been reported that addition of lower valence dopants into La2O3, such as Mg2+, decreases the energy of formation of vacant sites while the same type of dopants drop to a high extent the activation energy of methane activation step [99,100]. On the other hand, higher valence dopants may interact with the different oxygen species and thus their contribution to the CH4 activation was small. Based on the XRD analysis (Fig. 2) presented herein for the La-Mg-Ce and Li/La-Mg-Ce, the incorporation of La3+ ions into the crystal structure of CeO2 led to the formation of a La-Ce-O mixed oxide, creating oxygen vacancy sites, which could improve the formation of electrophilic oxygen species. Moreover, the simultaneous presence of Li+ (0.76 Å) and Mg2+ (0.72 Å) and the increased calcination temperature probably caused the modification of the structure, morphology, and defect of MgO instead of forming the [Li+O−] active center [58].Raman experiments (Fig. 3) confirmed the formation of the mixed oxide La-Ce-O and that the addition of Li+ ions caused numerous changes in the structure of the catalysts, such as LaO8 defects, oxygen vacancy sites and the formation of O2 2− peroxo and O2 – superoxo species. Furthermore, based on the XPS (Fig. 6) analysis, it was also argued that the addition of La3+ into CeO2 (La-Mg-Ce support) reduced the amount of lattice oxygen species, suppressing the total oxidation of CH4 and improved the reaction of OCM. Regarding the Li-based samples, it can be assumed that the addition of lithium ions enhanced the formation of superoxide species in corroboration with the results for the Raman analysis. The highest peak at ≈ 533 eV was observed for the Li/Mg-Ce sample. Also, the simultaneous incorporation of La3+ and Mg2+ did not favor further the formation of superoxide ions, but kept almost unaffected the concentration of carbonate species, which as will be shown below, possibly participate as active sites in the catalytic cycle of OCM. Finally, Gambo et al. [91] reported that the nature of the oxygen species has an impact on the surface reducibility and in particular, the existence of more electrophilic lattice oxygen results to a lower surface reducibility. Surface Reducibility: Another key factor that needs consideration is the surface reducibility of the oxide catalytic samples. Kumar et al. [101] proved that oxides with low surface reducibility (high reduction temperature) lead to a low rate of C-H bond activation and increase C2 selectivity. Thus, catalytic samples with increased surface reducibility (low vacancy formation energy) are expected to present reinforced OCM activity and decreased yield to C2 hydrocarbons. Gu et al. [102] studying the effect of different dopants (e.g., Li, La, Mg, and Ce) in Na2WO4/SiO2 catalysts and the influence on the surface reducibility and catalytic activity, reported that the Mg, Li and La showed lower standard reduction potential than Ce, resulting to lower conversion values of CH4 and higher olefin and paraffin selectivity values. From the H2-TPR experiments (Fig. 5) presented herein, the addition of dopants (Mg2+ and/or La3+) led to the reduction of CeO2 at lower temperatures due to the presence of more active surface oxygen species. However, for the promoted Mg-Ce and La-Mg-Ce supporting materials, the shift of the reduction at lower temperature may also be caused by the smaller crystallite size of CeO2. Surface Carbonates: The existence of surface carbonate species is also thought to have a significant influence on the OCM reaction. For example, Dubois et al. [103] investigated the catalytic performance of alkali, alkaline earth, and rare earth oxides and reported that peroxycarbonate ions (CO4 2–) are initially formed during the reaction between the surface superoxide ions and carbonate ions (Eq. (11)), and as a second step, peroxide ions are produced (Eq. (12)); the latter are important active site for OCM and the further production of ethylene. It has also been argued that carbonate species provide active sites on the catalyst surface [104,105]. In particular, Korf et al. [104] argued that the active sites for the OCM process are formed from the decomposition of surface lithium carbonates species due to oxygen in the gas phase, an argument that was also supported by Kimble et al. [105]. (11) CO 3 2−+O 2 −→CO 4 2−+O − (12) 2O −→O 2 2− On the other hand, Mirodatos et al. [106] and Xu et al. [107] argued that carbonate species, formed by the presence of CO2 during the reaction of OCM, have a negative effect in the catalytic activity and selectivity. In particular, according to the study of Xu et al. [107] catalyst deactivation could be avoided by having the appropriate concentration of CO2 and high reaction temperature. Furthermore, Korf et al. [104], argued that catalyst deactivation due to carbonates is only favored in high concentrations of CO2 during the reaction. The use of Li species as a promoter is also thought to be an important factor that influences the catalytic activity and selectivity towards the desirable products. Lunsford [30] reported that the interaction between Li species and MgO onto the catalyst surface, generated [Li+O–] active sites, which were responsible for the production of methyl radicals by abstracting hydrogen from the molecule of methane, improving the catalytic activity and selectivity. Li+O– pairs as OCM active sites: Ito et al. [39] reported on the mechanism of [Li+O–] formation and argued that the oxygen of the gas phase reacts with the surface oxygen vacancies at high temperature, producing O2– species and holes (h+). The [Li+O–] active sites are formed as O2– ions and are trapped into the holes adjacent to Li+ ions. In the case of cerium-based samples, Tang et al. [55] reported that the simultaneous presence of Li species and CeO2 could lead to the formation of [Li+O–] and to the reduction of Ce4+ to Ce3+, generating the appropriate surface oxygen species and electron holes for the adsorption and activation of CH4 to form methyl radicals (Eq. (13)). (13) O (ads) −+Ce 4++[Li + e − h +]→Ce 3++[Li + O −]+h + In contrast, several other works have questioned the existence of the [Li+O−] sites at real OCM reaction conditions [59,89,108,109], and therefore, their catalytic relevance. In particular, Luo et al. [109], employing synchrotron VUV photoionization mass spectroscopy, and Schwach et al. [59] in particular argued that Li acts as a structural modifier of the active MgO instead of as an active site. 4 Conclusions From the work presented herein, it is clear that the incorporation of lithium species onto the structure of the supporting materials had a great affect in the activity of OCM, as it changed the reaction pathway, leading to an increased production of the desirable products (C2H6 and C2H4). The existence of promoters (La3+ and/or Mg2+) had an effect on the catalytic performance when a decreased CH4/O2 ratio was used, mainly at temperature higher than 750 °C. This may be attributed to the excess oxygen of the gaseous phase which regenerate the appropriate active sites of the catalytic samples. The presence of Mg2+ into the structure of Li/Mg-Ce led to an increase in the population of intermediate basic sites and to the amount of surface superoxide species; these characteristics improved the catalytic activity in terms of CH4 conversion and production of ethylene via the dehydrogenation of ethane. The presence of La3+ in the Li/La-Mg-Ce system led to a 25% increase in CH4 conversion at medium reaction temperatures, and strongly improved the production of C2 hydrocarbons (SC2 higher than 80% between 725 and 800 °C). However, the presence of La3+ also led to a reduction in ethylene production, probably due to the lower concentration of surface superoxide species. Finally, the investigation of the effect of contact time on the catalytic activity proved that at lower WGHSV the formation of ethylene via the dehydrogenation of ethane was favored due to the enhanced residence time between the surface superoxide species and C2H6. coredata.dc:description: The work presented herein reports on the oxidative coupling of methane (OCM) performance of a series of Li-free and Li-doped CeO2 and CeO2 modified with Mg2+ and La3+ catalysts. The supporting materials (Ce, Mg-Ce and La-Mg-Ce metal oxides) were synthesized using the microwave assisted sol-gel method, while lithium ions were added using the wet impregnation technique, to further affect the physicochemical properties, activity and selectivity of the materials, in terms of the desirable hydrocarbon products (C2H4 and C2H6). The materials were characterized towards their textural, structural and redox properties, surface basicity, and surface morphology using N2 adsorption/desorption, X-Ray Diffraction (XRD), Raman spectroscopy, CO2-Temperature Programmed Desorption (CO2-TPD), H2-Temperature Programmed Reduction (H2-TPR), Scanning Electron Microscopy (SEM), and X-ray Photoelectron Spectroscopy (XPS). Catalytic activity was assessed between 600 and 870 °C, at atmospheric pressure and different CH4:O2 molar ratios and Weigh-basis Gas Hourly Space Velocity (WGHSV). It is concluded that low specific surface area values, the existence of surface moderate basic sites, increased concentration of oxygen vacancies and the presence of electrophilic oxygen species (O2 – and O2 2–) on the catalyst surface had a crucial role on the improvement of the catalytic performance in terms of the desirable products, mainly ethylene. It is noted that the addition of Li changed thoroughly the reaction pathway and the products’ distribution, with the C2 selectivity values exceeding 85%. The Li/Mg-Ce catalyst, presenting the higher population of intermediate basic sites and surface superoxide species, showed an improved catalytic activity in terms of XCH4 and production of ethylene, while the incorporation of La3+ into the crystal structure of CeO2 suppressed the production of ethylene. Finally, smaller CH4:O2 molar ratios suppressed the production of hydrocarbons, while enhanced residence times, favoured the dehydrogenation of C2H6 to C2H4.
coredata.dc:title: Oxidative coupling of methane on Li/CeO2 based catalysts: Investigation of the effect of Mg- and La-doping of the CeO2 support
